Award.AwardTitle: SYMPOSIUM: Support for U.S. Participants for the Symposium on "Statics and Dynamics of Dense Granular Matter," July 6 - 10, 2015, Madrid, Spain

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1460426
PI: O'Hern, Corey

This project will support the participation of US scientists and engineers in a symposium titled Statics and Dynamics of Dense Granular Matter, which will be held during the European Solid Mechanics Conference in Madrid, Spain from July 6 - 10, 2015. The symposium will focus on dry granular materials, which are suspensions in which the only interaction between particles occurs when they contact each other. The symposium will provide a way for leading research groups in the U.S. to interact with their European counterparts and other researchers from around the world. Participation by junior researchers will be encouraged.

Dry granular materials appear in a variety of important industrial and natural processes. These materials pose special problems when they are processed in the dense state, because they can undergo a transition between a flowing and jammed state. The characteristics of jamming depend not only on the granular material but also on the process that leads to jamming. This symposium will cover a range of topics for such materials including packings of frictionless and frictional particles, granular suspensions, constitutive laws for dense flows, shear-induced jamming and shear thickening, and geophysical applications involving granular materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This small award supported travel expenses for 12 scientists from the United States to attend and present talks at two mini-symposia that focused on dense granular materials at the 9th European Solid Mechanics Conference in Madrid, Spain from July 6-10, 2015.  The topics of the mini-symposia included shear jamming of frictional and non-spherical particles, intruder penetration in static packings, erosion of granular beds arising from fluid shear flows, continuum modeling, stick-slip behavior, avalanches, microstructure of static packings and during flow, and discontinuous shear thickening. This award allowed scientists from the granular materials research community in the U.S. to interact with researchers from Europe who focus on similar problems. This travel award has led to the development of several collaborations between researchers in the U.S. and Europe.  In addition, the participants of the mini-symposia identified important open questions that are ripe for future research, for example, yielding and strengthening behavior that occurs ubiquitously in nearly jammed particulate systems.  In response, the supported participants are organizing a follow-up summer program entitled "Statistical Mechanics Close to Jamming" at the Aspen Center for Physics in July 2017, which will focus on yielding and strengthening behavior during granular flows. It is clear that greater interactions between scientists in the U.S. and Europe will lead to more rapid breakthroughs in understanding dense, particulate packings and flows.
